source.citation: From: Munir, A.A. (2002). A taxonomic revision of the genus Verbena L. (Verbenaceae) in Australia. Journal of the Adelaide Botanic Garden 20:21-103.

leads.lead_text: Inflorescence pubescent to puberulous, neither glandular or viscid; bracts puberulous abaxially during anthesis, glabrous after anthesis; upper leaves narrow-linear, entire or divided into long narrow lobes or long teeth
Inflorescence hirsute or pubescent, glandular or viscid; bracts hirsute or pubescent to puberulous abaxially; leaves variously incised, lobed, dentate or serrate
Lower and mid-stem leaves divided, incised, or dentate-serrate almost to midrib; bracts usually as long as calyx, occasionally two-thirds the length of calyx
Lower and often mid-stem leaves coarsely toothed or incised to lobed, not deeply divided; bracts c. half the length of calyx
Leaves not deeply divided, segments short, obtuse, more or less dentate; bracts usually up to half length of calyx, rarely the same length as calyx
Leaves deeply divided, segments long, narrow, acute, serrate; bracts usually half to two-thirds length of calyx

Flowers sessile; rachis with glandular and non-glandular hairs; calyx teeth distinct; corolla-tube cylindric, constricted below limb, puberulous in upper half outside; bracts narrowly ovate-lanceolate, usually up to two-thirds length of calyx, rarely longer

Flowers both sessile and with short pedicels 0.5–1.5 mm long; rachis with glandular hairs only; calyx teeth minute or indistinct; corolla-tube somewhat broader near top, not constricted below limb, glabrous to glabrescent outside; bracts ovate, up to half length of calyx
